reviewText: Well Well Well finally there is someone who has dvd rights to a soap opera who understands why soap fans love soaps.  If you don't understand why soaps are different than any other tv genre, you release things like 2 discs full of unrelated episodes with no story to tell. This is what we want, this is what we will spend our hard earned money on, this is why we love soaps - the WHOLE story, all the scenes, all characters, no matter how nominal, every detail no matter how pointless a scene seems to be, no matter how "unnecessary" an episode seems to be in regard to an overall storyline, all of it matters, because it is about the people and the stories, the who and the why and the when, not just the "major" episodes from a story, not just the characters in big stories, not just the scenes related to a single story, ENTIRE EPISODES ALL IN A ROW.If there were the high chance of many releases of many soaps, over time, I would rate this lower because for the price, it is a complete rip-off.  At this rate, if they are all released, I'll go broke trying to get them.  However, since it is the first release and I have wasted all my ability to hope on SoapClassics, I will assume we won't get the other soaps we want and not much more of B&B; either, in which case, this deserves 5 stars for releasing it properly - not a few of each of the first 3 years epoisodes crammed together with no story, but the way we want it - 16 in a row, in full.I didn't ever watch B&B; and don't watch it now, so I am not connected to the characters yet, like I would be if it was another soap - sticking with Bell, I'd choose Y&R; from the beginning before B&B; - or if its one I haven't watched, I'd rather any of the much older cancelled soaps, because you can get it from beginning to end evntually.  However, since I love soaps and the idiots at the networks are taking them all away for horrible daytime replacements of more shows telling me what to do and how to live, I'll take whatever I can get from the soap world - if it is episode all in a row, not picking and choosing.The joy of the older soaps (before my time) would be similar to B&B; - I've never seen any of it, its all new to me, so there won't be anything I already know about, or the outcome, or who loved who or who killed who or anything else.If we are blessed with many many more or the rest of B&B; or other Bell shows, I beg of you, bigger sets, more episodes, at a reasonable price.  8 hours for $20 is just completely unreasonable.  But not so big that they are $200-400 sets, try some middle of the road sets of $30-60 so we get  alot more hours but can still afford it a few times a year.  Soap fans are just regular people, we don't have a gazillion dollars.  Also, I need episodes, not extras - as great as extras would be - old footage, bloopers, old interviews, etc...I would rather pay for more episodes and have a separate disc sold with extras that we can buy in-between episode releases.Thank you to everyone who had anything to do with getting this accomplished and for all your hard work - I hope it pays off, and allows you to provide the world with many many more soaps released JUST LIKE THIS....aside from the cost.

reviewText: Glad to see B&B on DVD. I snatched this up when it came out. It is great revisiting the beginning of B&B but the picture quality for the DVD is awful. The show gets 5 stars but the picture quality gets 1 star thus averaging to a 3 star.
summary: Bold and Beautiful but grainy picture

reviewText: It's great that the suits at CBS has finally released this version in the US after having sets released overseas for years. Seeing how some storylines and characters evolve over the last 25 years has been great. With the recent departures of Ronn Moss and Susan Flannery, it's especially cool to see them in their early days of B & B. Looking forward to future releases.

reviewText: Obviously the Bell family, who owns the rights to "The Bold and the Beautiful" (the world's most-watched soap opera) saw the incredible sales of the Proctor and Gamble owned soaps "Guiding Light" and "As the World Turns" had on DVD so now comes an "official" DVD release of "B and B" featuring the series' first 16 episodes.See how the stories all began back in the early spring of 1987 when Stephanie Forrester first met Brooke or when Ridge met Brooke and how the Forrester family made a solid mark in the California fashion industry.What is amazing about these shows all 16 episodes were written soley by its creator William J. Bell while he continued to write "The Young and the Restless".The stories are involving and many smack of the early days of "Young and Restless", but still the serial became known for the solid performance of Susan Flannery, an Emmy winner for her work on "Days of Our Lives", as Stephanie whom soap opera historian Chris Schemering called "a fascinating alabaster sphinx of a woman".Let's hope there are more sets like this to follow!
Title: N/A

NOT AN OFFICIAL PRODUCT. DON'R BUY IT.
